For I'm enough dishonour'd, and asham'd
To breath, but in the Air, where Love is nam'd.
But be disgrac'd with an attempt so foul,
I hate this place, the World, the Gods, my Soul.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Tempest ended? and no mischief done?
Calisto's Innocence unshaken stand?
This horrid Storm must be again begun.
I'le fly to Heaven, as Psecas gave command:
And to my Queen with Lyes my self address,
And bring again that raging Lioness.
Mean while I'le charm the Nymphs within this Grove:
Around, around here let'm rove:
And Visions guard the Sacred ground,
To fright 'em still within their bound.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: How am I kept a Prisoner, in the Power
Of this base God? Oh! that revenge to have
I were some mighty Goddess for an Hour:
Oh! how I would torment the Heavenly Slave?
But see! my Sister here? and oh! my Fears
Her lovely Face all delug'd o're with Tears.
Ah! what means this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Sister here? be gone,
Leave me to my disorder'd self alone;
And fly these Groves, they are the curst abodes
Of Satyrs, Fiends, or worse, of Impious Gods.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! how you fright me? I grow pale with fear;
What fatal accident has happ'ned here?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'm too disorder'd now Replies to make!

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: No matter, I will no denial take.
What has befallen you since I parted hence?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What you to hear have too much Innocence.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Not let me know it? this unkind appears;
I will both hear it, and have all the Tears.
To yonder mournful Shades let us repair,
Which to our sorrows some resemblance bear:
And there to tell your Griefs your Task shall be,
And I will sit and weep for you, and me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: COrydon is a Noble Swain,
And too long has felt disdain:
But since scorn I once did show,
My Love I'm too proud to let him know.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l:
Ah
Sylvia! Sylvia
! my Heart (like yours)
Pain from foolish Pride endures.
I angry with Strephon to day did appear,
And now long to reconcile;
Yet in pride for a time will seem severe,
Though it breaks my Heart the while.

div.stage:
Enter
Strephon, Corydon, Chorus
of Shepheards.
Daphne and Sylvia offer to go as they Enter.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh whither does my lovely Daphne fly?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l:
How long will
Sylvia Corydon
deny.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: It is my Will my kindness to remove.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I shall never, never Love.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh! what has chang'd my Daphne's mind?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Oh false, and cruel Woman-kind!

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Come Shepheards do not complain.
See, see yonder a merry Train,
Of Gypsies dancing over the Plain.
Call 'em straight, Call 'em straight to comfort these poor Swains.

div.l: No longer complain,
If your Loves shew disdain,
Be proud and disdain 'em again.
The Fools you will find
Will be glad to be kind,
When they once are despised by the Men.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Hark, Hark! in yonder Woods the Satyrs Play,
The Ecchoes bring their Laughs this way.
They with some pleasant sport are pleas'd.
The wanton Demy-Beasts some Nymphs have seiz'd.

div.l: Laugh Shepheards, Laugh and Sing;
Joyful Tydings now we bring.
The Fair Calisto is disgrac'd;
Gods and Mortals hate the Chast.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: All this to me but little ease does give.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: All Joys are dead to me, why do I live?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: In death alone we ease shall find.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: In death alone we ease shall find.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l:
of all
. oh false and cruel Woman-kind!

div.head: ACT. IV.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: HOW long will these malicious Woods in spight
Conspire to hide my Goddess from my sight.
Were the Truth known, she is in private gone
To some blind Cave with her Endimion:
For busie Tongues are with her Honour bold,
Or she with Love does Correspondence hold.
Some beautious Youths that do her fancy please,
Have reconcil'd those bloody Enemies;
I scorn and hate her, (though these falshoods be)
That she delights in anything but me.
At her my generous Revenge does aim,
I in Calisto would my Goodess shame.
But ha! my Vassal Mercury so nigh?
Put me in humor with some pleasing Lye,
For my lost Goddess I can no where find.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I bring you News (my Nymph!) will tune your mind,
Much better News then did I only aim
To please and flatter you my wit could frame.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Speak! the Expectation does delight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The minute that I parted from your sight,
Our jealous Queen descended from above,
And found Calisto (as you wish't) with Jove.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Joy! and kill'd her streight?—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She was debarr'd,
The Nymph was then under her Lovers Guard,

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: What strange Event must that Encounter have?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: All his Queens Rage my Monarch did outbrave.
With her fair Rival forc't her to comply,
Nay, ask her pardon for her Jealousy.
Not daring then to truth her with his Love,
Compell'd her to return, and fled above.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Tyrant! That I had been his Queen an hour,
I would have plagu'd and exercis'd his power!
Will Juno then put up Affronts so rude?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, No, the angry Queen I strait pursu'd,
Fir'd all the Mines of Sulphur in her Soul,
The active Flame through ev'ry Vein did rowl,
That she wept Fire, and her whole Soul did blaze.
The frightned Gods, did at the Wonder gaze,
Believ'd the World once more with Fire undone,
And Jove lookt round for a new Phaeton.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: The World for Ruine surely must prepare!
Let her destroy it, ere Calisto spare.
Oh! I'm impatient till she does appear,
Why tarries Juno? when will she be here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ere you can think again— I left her now
This instant standing on the shining brow
Of a Celestial Arch, of wondrous height,
With her Robes girt, and ready for her flight.
Calisho's dead by this time, or at least
Roaring beneath the figure of a Beast.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Shall she be a Beast?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If any ease
It will give you, she shall what Beast you please.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Let me think!— Some very ugly one,
Uglier than yet by Nature e'r was shewn
With all her skill and power, let Juno try
To outwit Nature in deformity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She shall observe your pleasure to the full,
She shall discover Natures fancy dull.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My most obedient Deity! But stay,
May not Calisto have escap't away,
And found our Goddess, whil'st you fled above?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I charm'd both her, and Nyphe in that Grove.
There round they wander, chac't by panique fear,
Take for a sighing Ghost each wind they hear;
At their own Voices start, and Shadows stare,
And think the lofty Trees tall Fantoms are.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Observ'd to every tittle my Command;
Nay, guest my very wishes, take my hand,
Here pay thy self, for thou hast pleas'd me so,
My Favors unpetition'd I'll bestow▪
Now Nyphe's Ruine I must next contrive;
For no one my displeasure shall survive.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For her disgrace do not disturb your thought;
Go, let your Goddess to the Grove be brought.
To shew her Fav'rites virtues there pretend,
My jealous Queen will soon your Cause defend.
Calisto's fall will some dishonour throw
On her young Friend, and to pursue the blow,
Charge her with confidence of Love to me.
Then I, as if I fear'd discovery,
And of my Mistriss Honour cautions were,
Will gently call, but so as all may hear,
Nyphe my Love.— My Nyphe, why so slow!
Come to me here, for I impatient grow.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: How active in Invention dost thou prove?
Thou half deserv'st the glory of my Love.
I could descend to smile now, if I durst;
But that's too great a Favor at the first:
And to rash Youth 'tis an unhappy Fate▪
To come too early to a great Estate.
Much Wealth, much Honour, I design my Slave,
But I the management of all will have.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My glorious Mistriss, does her kindness shew,
With the vast wealth, I should distracted grow.
But yet some mark of Favor let me wear,
This little Arrow from your Quiver spare.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: 'Tis thine!— But stay, not that, the Dart you have,
My Goddess in reward of Service gave,—
No matter, take it, I her Favors slight;
Nay, to affront her, wear it in her sight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How will I strut among the Powers Divine
With this, and make 'em at my Fortune pine?

sp.speaker: Psecas?
sp.l: Knight my self I now declare,
And this the Badge of my Queens Order wear.
But see the Nymphs walking their Fairy round,
This of their Circle is their utmost bound.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Let me run and wound e'm with my Eye!
But now I think on't— by my Frowns to dye,
Will be a Fate too glorious and sublime,
And I shall look e'm dead before their time.
They are of use that Huntress to disgrace,
Which 'cause she is of a Celestial Race,
Usurps the Title of a Power Divine,
Though her Deserts inferiour are to mine.
Howe'r by Birth she's not below my hate,
I'll shew her Folly, and dismiss her strait.
Then these may live.—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: See! See! I have descryed
Your Goddess.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There by that Rivers side—
Run, Run, my Queen!

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: In yonder Thicket stay
Till my Return—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My Queen I shall obey.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How long shall we this black, this cursed place,
The hated horrid Scene of my disgrace,
In wild and frightful Mazes wander round?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Sure we are here by black Inchantments bound.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where ere we go, wild shapes around us move!
And every Tree appears to me like Jove.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: These frightful shadows are his Guard I fear,
And for some black design, imprison us here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: They are! What shall we for our safety do?
Run, and the Fantoms swiftlier pursue!
Shoot, and our Arrows flie we know not where,
Are lost in Mists, or onely wound the Air.
They come!— Stand off ye Fiends!—

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: How pale they shew?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And every thing is blasted where they go.
That some brave Man of the old Tytans Race,
Would help me to revenge my great disgrace.
If any God will tempt my Soul to Love,
Let him depose that hated Tyrant Jove.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! That the Gods should be such wicked things!
Now this into my Soul the Reason brings,
Why Heav'n is hated by the Young and Fair;
It seems, the Deities abuse 'em there:
For which, the old and slighted do not care.
Is it for this Priests bid us worship Jove?
Are these the Joyes they promise us above?
But we are safe, my Goddess does appear.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Disguis'd again the Tyrant Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Do you not see the Nymphs around her there?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Cheats, Fantoms, all!— Delusions of the Air.
My heart of fears for you (sweet Nyphe) ease!
Leave me to suffer my own miseries.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Why with unkindness do you Love repay?
I hope you do not think I will obey.
Besides, I'm fetter'd in Inchantments too,
Though I need none to fasten me to you.
The foolish Gods may their Inchantments spare,
Stronger than theirs about your self you bare.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fortune who sends me Suff'rings, does in you
Send me the sweetest of all comforts too.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Discourse no more, I cannot bravelier dye,
Than in your aid, and by a Deity.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then let us bravely perish in defence
Of injur'd Chastity and Innocence;
And when we both are dead, oh! if there be
In Heav'n, but any Friend to Chastity.
Some Goddess, of our purity have care,
And to some private Tomb our Bodies bare.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The chaste Calisto sin? if thou woud'st try
To scare us with some frightful Prodigy,
Thy stories within bounds of Reason feign;
Those who out-talk their mark, derision gain.
Who use Invention must with Art proceed!
They, of all Merchants, the most cunning need.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I scorn the Traffick, and your Friend, nay you
May Love, ere I speak any thing untrue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Of one most useful Virtue you have store,
Of Confidence, to charge you with no more.
But know, no ill can her fair Soul invade!
Her whole Composure is for Virtue made.
Her Body of so pure a mold is wrought,
Her very Body may a Soul be thought!
A Soul to highest Purity refin'd!
Visible Virtue, a Celestial Mind
Condens't to Beauty, in that fair disguise
Descending to the view of humane eyes.
Gross Passions can no more find dwellings there,
Than Men can breath in the Aetherial Air.
There is no Fuel there for earthy Fire,
The starving Flame must instantly expire.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! How much curious Art you make appear?
How finely you would paint us nothing here?
Your Colours are so fine, your Strokes so small,
That they no Strokes, nor Colour have at all.
I know not how invisible, and pure
Her Body may be, 'tis not so obscure,
But you may see her now in yonder Grove;
There but this instant in the arms of Jove,
She humbly condescended to my view.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I say 'tis false! Nay, it is Nonsense too.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Nonsense to see! That does indeed surprize▪
Nymphs in your service must have witty Eyes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That it is Nonsense, I again proclaim,
The Gods for her must a new Nature frame,
Ere Sin in her the least possession gains!
No longer then Calisto she remains,
Who sayes Calisto then does spot her Fame,
Sayes she's at once another, and the same.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: How for Calisto you employ your Wit?
How virtuous 'tis to be a Favourite?
Her Crimes with glosses as you please disguise,
You shall not argue me out of my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Proceed in insolent Contention still?
Cease your Disputes! And know it is my Will,
You never more presume to touch her Fame,
Nor mention, but with high Respect, her Name.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Gods! Gods! to rev'rence her I much incline!
What pity 'tis she is no Power Divine?
Yes! I will spread her Virtues, and your own,
What Virtues too they are, shall well be known.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Call in dispute my Virtues?— Seize her there!

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Is this the Love to Chastity you bear?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Who boast of it so much, oft-times have none!

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My Chastity is equal with your own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Amazing Pride!— Confine her.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: If you dare.
I'll work on Flowers the story with my hair;
Which round the World some courteous wind shall blow,
Till it with Zeal into a Tempest grow.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: With Pride and Malice she begins to Rave;
Conveigh her to some Beasts forsaken Cave.
I doom her by her restless self to dwell,
And that at once both Fury is, and Hell.

div.stage: As they are guarding her out, Enter Juno, who stops them.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Hold! Goddess, Do you thus your Nymphs reward,
That with such Loyalty your Honour guard?
Is this the place where Chastity's profest?
Has Love so strong a party in your Breast?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Has Love in any Breast a greater Foe?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do you your Hatred to that Passion shew,
By guarding those who wrong my Bed and Throne?
Am I excepted from your Rules alone?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: On any such did e'r my Favour fall,
Who will not bear my Nymphs should love at all?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Does not this Nymph in seizure here remain,
For charging the most Vicious of your Train?
Whom you from Infamy defend with Might,
For no desert, but being your Favourite?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The merits of Calisto well I know,
My Favour rashly I on none bestow.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And shall my Eyes then be affronted too?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It was some shape abus'd both her and you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: That cursed shape still somewhere haunts this Wood,
And it shall bleed if it be flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: See! with Dart fixt, and Bowe completely beat,
She comes from yonder Grove.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: As if she meant
To give us an Assault.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And Nyphe there?—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Of Virtue she has much her Sisters share.
I thought to tell you (if I durst proceed)
How Mercury her forward Youth does breed,
And make already most expert in Love,
But I perceiv'd I should your Anger move.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ignorant Nature (if these Nymphs be ill)
To temper spotless Chastity wants skill,
Or flesh and blood is of too course allay,
And she may waste the fires of Souls away,
And in her vain Experiments grow old,
Ere that base Metal will be turn'd to Gold.
In them I'm sure she did at Virtue aim,
And never yet so near Projection came.

div.stage: Enter Calisto and Nyphe in a posture of defence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now, now the Satyr comes, let us prepare!

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Guarded around with Spirits of the Air
In shape of Nymphs.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let's make a brave defence,
Who knows what Charms may be in Innocence?
'Twas Virtue to the Gods their Godheads gave,
Dare they, what made 'em impiously outbrave?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: If that gave Godheads, we, who Virtue have,
Are above Gods, and Jove is but our slave.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fear not, but valiantly our selves defend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See! See! I think for Battel they intend.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Amazement! let us their intention know.
Princess, what mean you by that bended Bow?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Tyrant! I mean to guard my self from you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, and hate you too.
And will my Honour to the death defend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: This is your Royal Virgin.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: This your Friend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She knows her guilt too publick to be hid,
So does to Honour bold defiance bid.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why sacred Honour do you dare to name?
Is Honour, since we parted, turn'd to shame?
And Vice grown Virtue? Riddles you express.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That Virtue is a Vice which you profess.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Practise no more on us that stale deceit!
You wear that shape of Chastity to cheat.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The wonder almost stupifies my Sence;
Run Nymphs, and bring 'em here by violence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stand off you shapes, and do not venture near.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Go play your Masquerading tricks elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stand off, I say, if further you proceed,
If shapes have any blood, I'll make you bleed.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: See! to the height they Insolence pursue.
Now to all honour and esteem for you,
And everlasting farewell; now I'll know,
If against me you dare to bend your Bow.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: We dare, and will.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And could we make you fly
From your strong Guard of Immortality,
Let Heaven and Nature of themselves take care,
Or stand, or fall, to kill you we would dare.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I'm wounded!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They to Violence proceed,
And have presum'd to make a Goddess bleed. I
Immortal blood runs trickling from her veins.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! the infernal deed! fetch Engines, Chains!—

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They shall this instant at my Altars dye,
I will revenge my injur'd dignity.
Not Jove himself shall his lov'd Mistriss save.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: And I the honour of the Priesthood crave.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'Tis thine the glory to thy zeal is due.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Now all my malice is devotion too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Like one from strong infernal Chains unbound,
Whose Soul is after long distractions found,
To Sense and Reason, I begin to wake,
And doubt and tremble at my sad mistake.
Is it our Goddess? are you Nymphs indeed?
For Heav'n, for goodness sake, reply with speed.
Yet if you do, delusions still I fear,
Who will secure me it is you I hear?
I dare not trust my cheated ears or sight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ah! Princess! do you thus my Love requite?
Do I displease you then in being too kind?
And is this wound a punishment design'd?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Am I betray'd into so black a guilt?
Is it your sacred blood which I have spilt?
Oh! Look not on me with that wounding Eye,
Speak not, unless to sentence me to dye.
No other word but death I can endure,
My impious hands from farther ill secure.
Kill me, if you design Revenge to gain,
Ere I grow mad, and have no sense of pain.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: My Goddess cannot save me if she wou'd,
For I am fainting in her loss of blood;
If to her self she does Revenge deny,
I of her bleeding wound alone shall dye.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Now they begin again their Syrens Song,
The Tunes which charm'd my Goddess Soul so long.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Hope they to be forgiven Crimes like these?
Abuse at once two mighty Goddesses?
The spotless blood of chaste Diana shed?
And yet more horrid, durst invade my Bed?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Believe it, I will scorn to make defence,
Nor to beg Life, pretend to Innocence.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: The reason for it, is, but too well known!
In spite of you, you are ingenious grown.
This injur'd Queen, my Goddess here and I
May thank your guilt for so much modesty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Office, Nymph, I do not understand,
Who to implead us gave you the command?
From whom do you derive a place so high?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I shall inform you, 'tis from Mercury.
Her Charms that God her humble Vassal make;
He would not be a God but for her sake.
And she that she may kind, and grateful prove,
Revolts from Chastity, and sides with Love.
Nature has to th' amphibious Creature lent
An art to live in either Element.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Malicious! Will you wipe your stains on me?
And soyle my Honour with your Mercury?
Though could I bow to Love my Noble Sence,
Love then would be a thing of Excellence.
My Nature is so Godlike and Sublime,
That nothing I can do can be a Crime.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: My Mercury?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Yes yours, who should he be?
He durst not have presum'd to think on me.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Did I not find him with you making Love?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Did I not leave you with him in the Grove?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: You did, but do you not the Reason know?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Must I a Reason for your Vices shew?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Gods! Are there such things, as wrong, or right?
As Truth, and Falshood? And is Seeing, Sight?
If Truth be true, and Seeing be to see,
You love, and are belov'd of Mercury?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Which way can I such confidence confute?
But yonder's one will finish our dispute.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: See, Mercury indeed in yonder Grove!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Listen, he gently calls.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l:
within.] Nyphe
, my Love.
Steal to me, I will help thee safe away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Steal to thee? who art thou?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: within. Haste, haste away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Villain, Impostor, Had I but a dart,
I'd steal to thee, and fix it in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Now Truth is true, I hope, and Seeing sight,
Now pray inform us, who is in the right?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I am, and this some wicked Plot must be
Invented by thy lying God, and thee.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Astonishment! So soon to Vice begin?
Your youth an early riser is in sin.
Love is in so much haste he cannot stay,
But must set with you ere break of day.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Now where's your Chymistry? your beaten Gold?
Your spiritual flesh and blood? A finer mold
Than Souls are made of? All's a Cobweb Cell,
Where her black Soul does like a Spider dwell.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Embitter not thy words with Gall like this!
Treacherous Love has rob'd my Paradise,
And pluckt the fairest Fruit that there did grow;
The Gods in vain, plant Virtue here below.
It ripens not by any Sun or Time,
This World for Virtue is too cold a Clime.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Her thoughts, still for her Favourites, partial stay;
Virtue can sooner faulty be than they.
You may forgive the blood of yours they shed,
But she shall dye for injuring my Bed.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, let me dye! I many deaths would bear,
Rather than once these foul Reproaches hear.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Death on a Rack would be a greater bliss,
Than Life in such a lying World as this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Chaste Goddess, my Petition is to dye,
Hearken no longer to your Clemency;
Death for your sacred blood alone is due,
Let me not live to wound your Honour too.
I can a Plea produce yet (if I please)
Not only all my clamorous Enemies
Could vanquish, quite, but silence, if I wou'd,
The loudest cryes of your immortal blood.
Not only quell my Foes injurious hate,
But make your blood become my Advocate.
That very dart (would I the truth reveal)
Which wounded you, my bleeding Fame would heal.
But that would too much love for life display;
And I so hate the evils of this day,
My self I out of Fortunes way would hide!
My Innocence will for it self provide.
If that shines by me in my shady Tomb,
I shall sleep sweetly in that mournful Room,
And dream not of the Worlds censorious doom.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Unhappy Princesses, your Fate's severe!
Your Prayers I most unwillingly must hear,
Your Cause I cannot with my Honour own;
A torrent of misfortunes bear you down.
In spite of all my kindness you must dye;
Nay, I must banish too your memory.
What Plea you have your Innocence to clear,
I cannot guess; but I have cause to fear
None, that can all these Witnesses oppose:
At least, subdue the malice of your Foes.
If you shall suffer an injurious doom,
Oh! may your Honour blossom from your Tomb!
I'll build my Arbor there, and every hour
Come and bedew with tears the sacred Flower.
If you be faulty, and disgrace your due
Eternal shades conceal your names and you.

div.stage:
[Diana
goes off weeping, Nymphs Guard of Calisto and Nyphe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See! in deep sorrow she is parted hence!
Her love to Virtue is but a pretence—
She is unchaste her self.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Is that unknown?
Have you not heard of her Endimion?
Nor of her young Hippolitus that fled
From every Nymph, in private to her Bed?
She to the World has been a long mistake!
Pretends to Chastity for pleasures sake.
For secret Love does in the Forests dwell!
They understand each others meaning well.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She shall disgrace our dignity no more,
I will depose her from her heavenly Power.
And crown thee in her stead a Power divine!
I will!— the Empire of these Woods is thine.
Mean while I to my first Revenge will flie,
Thy Foes and mine shall at my Altars dye.—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! how I am transported with success!
Courted and sought by Fame and Happiness!
But how malicious does my Fortune prove?
Now he comes here to pester me with Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My fairest Queen!

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Thou troublest me, be gone!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What change is this?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I'm busied in fruition
Of a new Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you say this, to try
If with despair I at your feet will dye?
Name him.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My self.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh! Now farewell despair,
I hope in that fruition I shall share.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I must feign Love, that I may freedom gain.
Another time you shall.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh! where, and when?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Perhaps this Evening.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: In yonder Grove.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you not fail me?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Ask a Maid in Love,
If she will fail to meet with her delight?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With expectations of this pleasant Night,
Till it arrives, my thoughts I will employ.—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Do! Expectation's all you shall enjoy.
If in the Grove he tarries till he sees
Me there, he shall stay longer than the Trees.—

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh! whither are our poor despairing Shepherds gone?
I fear I have my Strephon slain,

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh my sorrow! Oh my pain!
Could I my Strephon find:
Could I my dearest Strephon find,
I'd never be unkind.
I'd never be unkind to him again.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I, my Love would passionately own,
Could I find my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Do I Dream? Do I Rave?
Look towards yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Our Shepherds come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv. Daph.
sp.l: Our Shepherds come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: From empty Pride I'll be free,
It shall bring no more mischief upon me,
Since I Love as well as he,
I'll not hazard my joy,
In being foolishly coy,
It had like to have undone me.

div.stage: Daphne and Sylvia go and meet Strephon and Corydon: each brings in her Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Dear Strephon, give despairing o'res,
Vnkindnesses are gone,
I never will be cruel to thee more.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Nor I to Corydon.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: O what kind God does Sylvia's hate remove?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And made at length my Daphne grateful prove?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Sylv. Daph.
sp.l: The gentle God of Love.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: Oh happy Tydings!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Blessed hour!
Ever kind and gentle Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Even kind and gentle Pow'r.

div.stage: Enter Chorus of Shepherds, follow'd by Bacchusses.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Joy Shepherds Joy! Diana's disgrac'd,
Love has had to day Revenge on the Chaste.
The Bacchusses here our mirth to improve,
Come hither to follow the Triumphs of Love.
No mirth without Bacchus, nor joy without Love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Since all our Grief thus joyfully ends,
Let each Shepherdess make her Shepherd amends,
To the Temple let's go,
And then we will show,
What every Lover, by Loving intends.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: THE time is past, whil'st vainly round I pace,
As yet encountring nothing in this place,
But the long Evening shadows of the Grove;
And shadows are but slender food to Love.
Not it is substance! substance! must delight
Loves wholsom frame and eager appetite.
Malicious Fortune, must this stay contrive
Some sudden ill to Psecas must arrive.
Nothing that's common could my Nymph retain,
For when Nymphs love, they fonder grow than Men.
Their melting hearts in kindness does excell;
And I am sure my Psecas loves so well,
That were she dead, her spirit would appear,
And leave th' Elizian joyes to meet me here.
Well, patience! patience! time rides proudly by!
And looks upon me with a scornful eye;
But I, in spite of all his swift Career,
Will overtake him, when my joyes appear.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: The mighty Victims ready to be slain!
Heavens Queen a Vassal to my merits grown.
Diana now no more my Soveraign;
The shady Empire of these Woods my own?
Th' impoverisht Stars have nothing to bestow,
But what for my acceptance is too low.
My next affair is quickly to Casheer
My loving patient Slave that waits me here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My Nymph appear? oh! now my Planets smile!
What has detain'd thee from me all this while?
〈◊〉 have been wandring here in grief and fear.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Who bid you do't? Could you expect me here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Can the kind Vows my Queen was pleas'd to make
Her just and noble Thoughts so soon forsake?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Do I such trifling Contemplations use?
Will I my Memory with you abuse?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Though I deserve not such a glorious place,
My Goddess will not from her Mem'ry chace
The noble Creatures which she being gave,
I mean, the promises she made her slave.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Well, if I did, I'll break 'em if I please!—
Am I oblig'd to keep my promises?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nothing can sov'reign Power oblige, 'tis true,
But its own will, that sov'reign Power have you;
But yet there is one mighty thing above▪
Even your own pow'rful Self, and that is Love.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Can any one such Insolence endure?
Love above me? You would affront me sure.
Who should, or can I Love? Where is there ought,
(Except my Self?)— that's worthy of my Thought?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True! But since Love to me you did express,
Your Love confers on me some worthiness.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My Love? Why can you think 'twas Love I meant?
Dare you to hope it be so insolent?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why?— should I rudely think you speak untrue?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Am I oblig'd to speak my Thoughts to you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you not Love then?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Dare you hope I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: What should I intend?
Should I with my own Slaves to Mirth descend?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And am I fool'd then?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Well! What if you be?
Is't a dishonour to be fool'd by me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And will you all my service thus requite?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Challenge Reward, as if it was your right?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your service then is with it self re-paid▪

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Supposing not? What service did you do?
Invent a Falshood? Shame a harmless Maid?
Well! when you please, I'll lye as much for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Exceeding well!— Did I then toyle and sweat,
At last, this Mockery to get?
None serve you for your Fools but heav'nly Powers▪

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Mortals are yours, you may sometimes be ours.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What? then I must to your Contempt submit?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I cannot help another's want of Wit..

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You do continue in your boldness still?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: 'Tis you are bold, who dare dispute my Will?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou empty foolish Female, who to please
Thy sickly Longings, with the fond delight
Of thy vain Sex, or rather their disease
Of Pride, resists thy nobler appetite.
Though now when thou so coy pretend'st to be,
Thou'dst give an Empire I would ravish thee.
But I'll not stoop to gratifie thee so;
That joy some bestial Satyr shall bestow!—
Ho! there!—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: A Rape! here!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Call out if you dare,
I'll all your Lyes and Villanies declare.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Rape! Rape! here!

div.l: So! 'tis well you do appear!
Virtue has excellent protection here.
Much safety your good Government affords,
The spreading Trees are not so full of Birds,
The Caves of Beasts, as all the Woods around,
Of wanton Gods who ev'ry where abound,
Waiting to make our Chastities a prey,
And Gins and Toyles do for our Honours lay.
On our occasions we can no where move,
But strait we fall into some Trap of Love.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dare you affirm it is a Fault of mine?
Can I the Gods to their abodes confine?
If they be weary of their heavenly bliss,
Must I be guilty?—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: You are too remiss.
And both our Honours and your own neglect.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: You are too bold, and full of disrespect.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Wherein do I that confidence express?
Is hate to Love and Vice grown sauciness?
Your pardon for my dullness I implore,
I never knew they were your Friends before.
It seems your meaning we must backward read▪
And we a Key to all your Cyphers need.
By Chastity, you zealous Love intend;
By Hate and Coyness, Kindness to a Friend.
Your nimble Wits have found it out;— but I,
Dull Fool, am hardned in my Chastity.
You should have plainly told me what you meant,
Before your wanton Gods to me you sent.
For I affront 'em all, and spoil the sport,
And quite disorder your mysterious Court.—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Immortal Gods! was e'r Celestial Power
In her own presence so blasphem'd before?
What? I am turn'd a Venus, and my Groves,
Private Retreats, and Nursery's of Loves.
Hence from my sight, and in the Forest howl,
In some Beasts shape, deformed as thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Stay Nymph, and flie to me, I'll have it known,
Here is a Power superior to her own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What in my Forrests here have you to do?
I in my Empire am supreme to you.
Go exercise your Goddesship above,
There you may share authority with Jove.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Your Nymphs diminish there my Royal due,
And I will have Reprisals here on you.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Her Love to Virtue now I hope is shewn,
And how much wrong I have her Honour done.
She has but one chaste Nymph in all her Train,
And she enjoys no rest till that is slain.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Boldness above belief!— I've watcht an hour
From all these cloudy Mists to set you free,
And disintangle the whole mystery,
And never yet could get it in my power.
I will no longer bear the pangs and throws,
I now will speak, and none shall interpose.
She then who dares your anger so outbrave,
Is my sworn Female, my devoted Slave!
Bought to my pleasure at no dearer Rates,
Than ruining the Nymphs she so much hates.
I help to gain her her malicious ends,
And for that hire my pleasure she attends.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! hellish falshood!—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I believe it true!—

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I think it false.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Th' opinion is my due!—
I scorn to fear he can my Fame remove.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That let th' event of my Relation prove.
I shall bring proofs will make your courage fall.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But I will hear it all.
Can you the honour of my Nymphs restore?
And are they innocent?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They are; and more,
Calisto's Virtue is above Divine,
And Nyphe at the least a Heroine.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: How he exalts the praises of his Love?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And flatters servilely the vice of Jove.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: In your own presence dares your Rival praise.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: To affront me, he does her Honour raise.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: He is no doubt the cause of your disgrace,
And first allur'd your Jove to her embrace.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What horrid Monster art thou? of what kind?
How fortified in body or in mind?
Under what species does thy Nature fall?
Or humane? hellish? or Divine? or all?
So many Gods thou dar'st deride, defie?
To conquer thee, will be a Victory
Great as the Sun's o're Python, nay above
That over all the Titans gain'd by Jove.
But with the force of Truth I'll make thee bow,
And yet will batter down that brazen Brow.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Melt it with shame!— For though she virtuous be,
Malice so great dishonours Chastity.
They should not dwell together in one Breast,
It is a Serpent in a Phoenix's Neast.
Say then, why call'd you Nyphe in the Grove?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Vile Psecas her dishonour to remove,
And fasten it on Nyphes spotless youth.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That was not wise, it would not look like truth,
To clear your stains with Innocence so pure.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Neatness alone some Maladies does cure.
Contagions soonest taint the finest blood,
Unwholsom Rooms they love to change for good.
But us on all these pikes her Virtue drove,
She chanc't to make discovery of our Love,
And rather chose a thousand deaths to dye,
Than hide a crime of the least infamy.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Where lodges truth, if Gods such Lyars be?
He knows all this is only true of me▪
Cause by my zeal his Nymph is doom'd to dye,
He sought Revenge here on my Chastity,
And now with falshoods does my Fame pursue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Against such confidence what can I do?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: What? but your self a foul Defamer own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Despise her boldness, and the truth make known.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am confirm'd that Psecas suffers wrong.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: If e'r did Nymph from a defaming Tongue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: With sacred Truth he does her Honour blast,
Why should I judge a mind so vicious, chaste?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nor Chastity, nor any thing that's good,
Can lodge in one that shares Calisto's blood.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My Vice, (I fear) to your disgrace will prove,
Too much severity to Vice, and Love.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Hermes! Release me from this Viper here!—
Who in my sacred Honour, does not fear
To fix her Teeth, and Venom to distill▪
On that, which is an antidote to ill.
Make but Calisto's Fame, as Nyphe's clear,
And this bold Nymph a punishment severe,
For all her Blasphemies shall quickly bear.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: When he clears her, then you do what you dare,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Her divine Virtues, and unspotted Fame,
Incense and Victims only should proclaim.
All wordish praise she is so much above,
That Eloquence would Prophanation prove.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! how the Woods must with her praises ring?
Such were the words entic't her to his King.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Praise on— and Pseeas's Reproaches slight,
Torment her envious Nature to the height.
And did Calisto triumph over Jove?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O'r him, o'r Pleasure, Empire, Glory, Love.
Despairing to subdue by open storm,
He first stole to her in your beautious form,
Hoping by ambush his design to gain;
And finding that fair stratagem in vain,
Himself and all his glory he display'd;
Himself his Heaven at her feet he laid,
He su'd, commanded, threatned, and implor'd,
Nay, wept, bow'd, kneel'd, and at her feet ador'd;
But could not or by promise, force, or guile,
Entice, compel, or cheat her to a smile.
Her Fort of Chastity to buy, to break,
Heaven was too poor, Omnipotence too weak.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: This to torment you sure is some design.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It tears my ears.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: 'Tis harmony to mine.
The brave Calisto's praise still boldly tell!
My Pleasure is their Rack, my Heav'n their Hell.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Fond Goddess, who triumphest in thy shame,
Preferring thy vain Fancy to thy Fame;
Contending in thy Favourites defence,
Against thy Honour, Reason, and thy Sence.
If all I can affirm no Faith can gain,
Believe thy wound, and listen to thy pain.
Hark how thy blood thy Favourite commends!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That very blood will prove her best of Friends.
And only be (when you the reason know)
To your malicious hopes a mortal blow,
Jove in your shape deep on her Soul imprest,
And strongly with the horror still possest.
The sight of you new terrors did awake,
She did your person for your shape mistake.
And that deceiv'd her to a Crime so brave,
She aim'd at Jupiter the blow she gave;
You of his sufferings alone complain,
You have the wound, but Jupiter the pain▪
A Crime will to her endless Fame redound.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Gods! then I must reward her for my wound.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You ought!— but how?— the Virtue she has shown,
Not all the Lawrels in your Woods can crown.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Happy the moment when my blood was spilt!
I'll now have Altars to my Victims built.
Their glory shall exceed their past disgrace!
Bring 'em in triumph here to my embrace.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Oh! Gods! this impious sentence who can bear?
This is a plot betwixt these Gods and her,
Wholly to ruine Virtue by degrees,
That they may love and revel as they please.
Nay, glory in it too, and make it prove
A Virtue worthy high rewards to Love.
And shortly all will Chastity disclaim,
And to be virtuous, will be thought a shame.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh! most provoking!—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Her reproach disdain,
Her sland'rous tongue shall quickly end its Reign.
I'll fetch a sov'reign Judge shall quell her pride,
And this debate impartially decide.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She names but half your villanous design,
You plot my glory too to undermine.
Ungrateful Jove, now weary of me grown,
Will place my Rival in my Bed and Throne,
And it is plotted here among you all!
And my severe Revenge on thee shall fall.
I'll kill thy Nymphs, thy Reputation blast,
Throw down thy Temples, lay thy Forest waste.
Thy self from Cave to Cave with Tempests chace,
And in the savage Beasts an instinct place;
To tell 'em who their Murderess us'd to be,
And make 'em for Revenge go hunt out thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh! foolish Rage! which will no Reason hear!
Your Fury against me I scorn to fear.
Alas! your anger at your equal flies;
But yet, perhaps, you may my Nymphs surprize.
I to their Innocence the more incline,
Your Honour to respect as well as mine.
But since you fight your own disgrace to prove;
I'll both defend 'em against you and Jove.
sp.stage:
[Enter
Calisto, Nyphe
vailed, brought in by Nymphs.
sp.l: Come Princesses! this posture is not due!
Truth has unvail'd it self, and so may you.
Your Beauties are not brighter than your Fame,
Falshood and Malice you have put to shame.
For the Rewards of Virtue now prepare,
And scorn the utmost which your Foes can dare.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Oh! What kind Power has the Truth reveal'd?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: One that has all our wounds entirely heal'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And your wound too! For unless that be whole,
My Honour may be well, but not my Soul.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: So well, that I am better than before!
My courage greater, and my pleasure more!
If I have any pain, 'tis that which flows
From the excess of joy, your Fame bestows:
The mark of which, upon my arm I bear;
The onely Jewel, I am proud to wear.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Glorious News! Who proves the Lyar now?
Great Goddess some Revenge to us allow.
The impious Author there of all this Evil,
Let's offer up a Victim to the Devil:
But she in mischief does so much excell,
Pluto, in fear, will keep her out of Hell.
She'll be a greater Plague than any there;
Furies themselves will be afraid of her.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Did ever Falshood Virtue so outbrave?
Great Goddess, on my knees, Revenge I crave.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You fierce, tempestuous Spirits of the Air,
Who late confin'd me, to my aid repair.
sp.stage: [Enter Spirits, the Nymphs stand on their Guard.
sp.l: The favour which you forfeited regain;
The Honour of your injur'd Queen maintain:
These bold Rebellious Nymphs in pieces tear,
And throw their Limbs in Whirlwinds round the Air.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Approach who dares! nay, for permission pray
To blow out of my Woods one Leaf away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Goddess! let 'em come! for I'm in pain
Till one of 'em at least by me is slain.

div.stage: As they are ready to Encounter, Enter Jupiter and Mercury.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Must I my Heav'n eternally forsake,
To quiet the disorders which you make?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Return'd again?— Oh! most tormenting sight!
There, I resign to you, your sole delight.
Make her your Goddess in the room of me,
I'll bear no more the Royal mockery,
Nor be a Statue to adorn your Throne.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And are you weary then of Empire grown?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am, and of my life!— And to be free,
Desire no blessing like Mortality;
That my own hand might pour out with my blood,
My sorrows and my life!—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I wish you cou'd!—
That both of us and all the World some ease
Might find of your eternal Jealousies.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Who is in fault?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Your folly is the cause,
For I will not be limited by Laws;
You but in part my kindness can enjoy,
My Ocean must a thousand Springs supply.
Once more I own this Royal Maid, I strove
To tempt by all the arts of Threats, or Love;
But 'gainst her Virtue did no more prevail,
Than the old Gyants when they Heav'n did scale.
They pil'd up hills on hills my Throne to seize,
I Mountains heapt of golden promises;
But found her Virtue from my reach as far
As from my Palace all their Mountains were.
Like those fond Fools when I was most sublime,
I did but in the reach of Thunder climb.
Her Soul shot down such Lightning from her Eyes,
Instead of spoiling, I ador'd my prize.
Once more embrace her then, and after this
The least injurious thought of her dismiss;
And Mercury the wrong which you have done
That fair young Nymph with low submissions own.
And to whatever suff'rings she thinks fit
To sentence you, with Penitence submit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I gladly to her fair Tribunal come,
And humbly on my knees attend her doom.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I recompence enough from this receive,
Revenge and Malice to your Nymph I leave.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And those good Virtues, which her gentle Mind
So much adorn, she shall rewarded find.
Now you, who with such zeal the ruine sought
Of these fair Nymphs, shall to your doom be brought.
I hope my words they credit may afford,
And all for truth acknowledge!—

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Oh! Insolence! Charge me with Falshood too?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Falshood, I hope, is false, though spoke by you.
Power gives not language the more truth or sence.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Astonishing! drag her to Torments hence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Spare her, for I my Honour scorn to owe
To her Acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: No, let her go.
For she has done, and let her suffer ill.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Now I will stay to contradict your will.
The Fondlings dandled upon Fortunes Knee
Nere sav'd, ('tis true!) from my conspiracy.
But to no merit have the least pretence,
Excepting pure insipid Innocence.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: We (with your leave) of that sole Judges are.
Oblige us now your Reason to relate,
Why you pursu'd the Nymphs with so much hate.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: My hatred stoop to have concern for them?
You much mistake, the Error I contemn.
Seeing what fondnesses abus'd your mind,
Having some kindness for you, I design'd
To disabuse you, set your judgment right,
And honour you with being your Favourite.
But since you from your own good Fortune go,
And have not Wit enough desert to know,
I throw you wholly out of my esteem,
And no submission shall the loss redeem,
Though in deep sorrow at my feet you fall;
For now I scorn you, nay, I scorn you all.
Gods, Goddesses, and Nymphs, away I'll flie,
And keep no more such trifling company.
I'll hunt alone, and in my self delight,
And be my own most dear-lov'd Favourite.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: She is grown frantick!

div.stage: [Psecas offers to go, is staid by Juno.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Rather she is brave.
Stay gen'rous Psecas, I thy friendship crave,
Bury not all thy worth in a Retreat;
Give me thy Love, and I will make thee great.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: A most harmonious friendship this must prove!
The Fates design'd 'em for each others Love.
For none love them, and they have love for none;
Their kindness centers on themselves alone.
And they are so exactly of a make,
Each may the other for her self mistake.
Now must the last and heaviest sentence fall
Upon my self the greatest Criminal.
My wretched self (as to my Crimes is due)
I doom to part eternally from you.
And to the pain of heav'nly joy to go;
But yet I must not leave you here below.
In pity to the World, I must remove
Those fatal eyes, out of the reach of Love.
Love must not here those killing darts retain,
To wound and torture Gods, and murder Men.
And yet to place you in my Heav'n, would be
Not your Reward, but my Felicity.
Some middle Region I must prepare,
Where all may with some ease your Beauty bear.
I then entreat, you will (to end this War!)
Accept the small dominion of a Star.
There you and beautious Nyphe may dispence
With cooler beams your light and influence.
On the great Ceremony Hermes wait,
Let all the Gods give their appearance strait.
These Virgins Consecration nought debars,
I'll in a full Assembly crown 'em Stars.

div.stage:
Enter
Strephon, Corydon, Daphne, Sylvia, Chorus
of Shepherds, as from the Temple.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Happy Lovers! happy Live,
And all the Gods their blessings give.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Lead along, and with Delight,
Let us hasten on the Night.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: What Vision's this is come to greet us?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: See! the Night is come to meet us.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: Stay gentle Swains be not afraid,
To see our Faces hid in shade.
We, but lately, were as fair,
As your Shepherdesses are.
Did not a frantick Youth of late,
O'reset the Chariot of the Sun?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: He did, and his deserved Fate
He met when he had done.

sp.speaker: 2 Afr.
sp.l: It is he that hath undone us:
He powr'd whole streams
Of melting beams,
Red, and glowing hot upon us.
And now we range the World around,
To see if our lost Beauty can be found.

sp.speaker: 3 Afr.
sp.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce: our Beauty's found,
Our lovely White and Red,
To two chaste Nymphs of Cynthia's Train is fled,
And they must Stars be crown'd:
And now instead of what we sought,
Our Black with us must fair be thought.
This happy Fate, who could Divine?
Our Beauty then in Heav'n must shine.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: No Losers we shall prove,
By parting with our Red and White;
If black will serve the turn of Love;
For Beauty's made for Loves delight.

sp.speaker: 3 Afr.
sp.l: See! See! the Nymphs are coming here.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: But Oh! what glorious Apparition's near?
The Clouds amazing Glories gild:
All the Clouds with Gods are fill'd.
And all the Gods appear.

div.stage: Calisto and Nyphe enter under a Conopy, supported by Africans; immediately upon their entrance, a Heav'n is discover'd, fill'd with Gods and Goddesses.
The whole concludes with an Entry of Africans; and this Song.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Must these be Stars? And to Heaven remove,
Before they have tasted the pleasures of Love.
That the Gods so ill, such Beauty should use!
What mighty Cost must Nature lose?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I cannot so much Beauty show,
But what I have, I'll better bestow.
Not upon Gods, or Glories above,
Or empty Renown, but Pleasure and Love.
All pleasure but love, from our hearts we'l be chasing,
We'l kindle our selves into Stars with embracing:
We'l every moment our pleasures renew,
Our Loves shall be flaming, and lasting and true.

div.head: The Epilogue spoken by Jupiter, who descended out of the Heaven, and addressed himself to Calisto and Nyphe.
div.l: THE Stars for your Reception now prepare,
And the ambitious Heav'ns expect you there;
But I will spoil their hopes, and break my vow,
For I've consider'd there are Stars enow:
And this inferiour World can scarce dispence
With the entire loss of so much Excellence.
With each of you I can oblige a Throne,
I'll keep you then to grace some Fav'rite Crown.
On that design you here shall still remain,
And I'll dissolve into a Nymph again.
Which will no less this fair Assembly please;
For Nymphs, in Courts, have sway like Deities.
You Wits who think you Gallantry display,
To laugh at ev'ry thing a God can say,
Will in good manners to a Nymph submit,
And own whatever Beauty speaks for Wit.
Perhaps the power of Beauty to express,
We choose our Language careless as our Dress.
None should come hither to attend, but gaze;
Here Beauties charms not Wits you ought to praise.
And 'tis your safest course, judge you of Show,
Fine Cloaths, and Faces, Tunes, and Dances too;
For those are things which you may chance to know.
There is no doubt but you have ears and eyes,
Your understanding most in question lies.
But what do I here trifling thus with these?
There are the Powers to whom we sacrifice,
In whose great Presence I may well allow
To lay aside my useless Godhead now.
You, Sir, such blessings to the World dispence,
We scarce perceive the use of Providence.
And since Your Rule such joy to all procures,
All should contribute what they can to Yours,
Wit by Your Smiles a Lustre do's maintain,
And Beauty keeps a long and happy Raign.
Your Right in them is therefore so entire,
They, above all, Your Pleasure should conspire.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
